metadata.titel_preek: The Surge of Dangerous, Restless Power

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God unlooses a restless, surging power into a 'frozen' world to shatter categories of death and despair, restoring full humanity and creating new socio-political possibilities.

subject.identificatie: God (Yahweh / The Power of the Resurrection)
tekstueel_bewijs: Yahweh is a God of odd, dangerous, surging power in the earth that unsettles and revamps
God is on the move in more ways than we can understand

object.identificatie: New Life / Full Humanness / Unfrozen Assets
tekstueel_bewijs: broken person restored to full humanity

zender.identificatie: The God of the Bible / The Easter Event
tekstueel_bewijs: The God of the Bible is an inscrutable power for life released in the world

ontvanger.identificatie: The Lame Man / The Church / The World / 'People like us'
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: Does hearer identify with Subject or Receiver?

helper.identificatie: The Church (Peter and John) / The Spirit / The Name of Jesus
tekstueel_bewijs: the church was a carrier of God’s power

tegenstander.identificatie: Worldly Authorities / Frozen Assets / Complacency and Despair
tekstueel_bewijs: worldly authorities are regularly baffled by this new power and resentful
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just 'bad behavior' but a structural 'frozenness' of reality (Death) that only a divine surge can break.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The hearer's response to the unloosed power: moving from 'frozen' assets to 'leaping and praising'.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer / 'Us'
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Permitting the new horizon / Rejecting old identities
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program is a response to the primary action of God. The hearer is invited to 'be on the side' of what God is already doing.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: The Spirit/Church → God's Power ← Worldly Authorities/Death

voorbeelden_god_subject: Yahweh is a God of odd, dangerous, surging power
God raised him from the dead
This power... is unloosed in the world
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we work hard to keep the boundaries secure
we also prefer to freeze our assets
you can be on the side of the newness

voorbeelden: we do not want our tea party upset
whether you can permit in your horizon
The story does not explain how this could happen
energy is given in the world for your newness
power that says you do not need to grovel

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is overwhelmingly focused on the endowment of Power (Pouvoir). It assumes the hearer lacks the ability to change and proclaims that the 'Surge' provides the necessary competence.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (Death/Frozen) to ~S2 (Despair/Begging), then introduces S1 (The Surge) which shatters ~S1 (Complacency/Control).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'unloosing' of power that is 'beyond all our controlled powers.'
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; S2 is described as a 'vicious cycle' and 'habits of deathliness' that destroy us.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God/Power is the primary actant. Human action is framed as a response to a prior, uncontainable divine initiative.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: whether you can permit in your horizon

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God is on the move in more ways than we can understand.
The old ways of greed and hate and fear are about to destroy us.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Peter and John are not 'heroes to imitate' but 'carriers' of a power they do not own. The lame man is a recipient of grace, not a model of faith-performance.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God acts, the church witnesses.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and 'dazzlement' rather than the burden of 'having to do'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic undertones; the power is 'unloosed' regardless of human permission, though permission is invited.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The primary program (God's power) and secondary program (human response) are perfectly ordered: power is given, then life is lived.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: power released among the nations that will stop the attraction of fear and hate and greed and war

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is seen as a 'frozen' state of the world that humans are powerless to 'unfreeze' themselves.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the narrative engine. The 'Power' is the actant that drives all change.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is a strong 'Grace' profile.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon could slightly more explicitly link the 'Power' to the person of Jesus to avoid it sounding like a vague 'energy'.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in theocentric narrative. It avoids the trap of turning the Easter story into a 'to-do list' for the congregation.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on Brueggemann's use of metaphors (frozen assets, tea parties), Greimasian analysis reveals that the 'engine' of the sermon is the transfer of Pouvoir (Power) from a Divine Sender to a Lame Receiver.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the historical context of Acts 4; this analysis shows how the sermon functions as a new narrative event for the modern hearer.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the 'Power' functions as an actant itself, almost a character that 'surges' and 'unsettles' independently of the human actors.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'Power' as a metonymy for God/Spirit, which keeps the focus on the 'Pouvoir-faire' modality.
